Straight thinker -

The federal government has balanced the budget, eliminated deficits for more than three years in just six periods since 1776, bringing in enough revenue to cover all of its spending during 1817-21, 1823-36, 1852-57, 1867-73, 1880-93, and 1920-30. We have also experienced six depressions. They began in 1819, 1837, 1857, 1873, 1893 and 1929.

Are you sure you want to pay down the debt?

There are two simple facts that SD cannot seem to grasp. One is:

The federal government can print money.

The U.S. can never go bankrupt unless we want to. It will run out of money the day after the NFL runs out of points. Now we cannot print arbitrarily large sums ad infinitum. When the economy has achieved its full potential or we have shortages, printing too much money will cause severe inflation. That is certainly not the case today.

The other fact is:

ONLY the federal government can print money.

No one else has a printing press. The population increases. The dollar loses value. The economy grows. As all this happens, the private sector needs more and more money. Only the federal government can provide the new money. The preferred way to do this is for the government to finance via gross deficits worthwhile projects such as infrastructure repair, education, research, etc. If we do this wisely, we will reap long term benefits and get money in the hands of the people who need it and will spend it, and out of the hands of the people who do not need it and will speculate with it.

What has happened if this fact is ignored? All 6 times we have eliminated deficits long enough to substantially pay down the debt, we have suffered a depression.

The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over while expecting different results.

We have (and Mr. Krugman's party in particular has) made a choice over the past couple of generations to to spend our public monies on transfer payments rather than infrastructure, etc. He might feel that we should simply devote an (ever?) increasing portion of our GNP to public spending, as after all, his party's leading presidential candidate commented just yesterday that "businesses and corporations do not create jobs" anyway - presumably only government does. Well, that's an opinion, but not one that is shared by a majority of American voters.

On the other hand, balanced budget amendments can be overcome by smoke and mirrors.  One has only to look at Wisconsin to see how a balanced budget can be achieved and tax breaks given out by offloading debt to bonds.

LML - Let's just look at economics to see why inequality is bad.

Experiments are hard to come by in economics, but we have a couple in the US to look at since WWI. There have been two medium long periods of very high inequality (Gini about 0.5), the 1920's and the 2000's. Both led to periods of disastrous economics, On the other hand, there was the long period of 1946 - 1973 (Gini about 0.25) which was a period of great prosperity. Since I do not place much faith in any economic theory, this evidence makes me believe that high inequality is very bad for the country.

But I know people like explanations. They want to know why. So I'll give it a shot.

1. Inequality depresses demand. A non-rich person must spend a greater percentage of his income to live than a Rich one. When many people are out of work, or are underpaid, when inequality is high, the non-rich do not have enough money to buy the stuff they need or want. They may want a new car, but they cannot afford it. This means businesses are not expanding because they do not have enough customers. You cannot create demand out of thin air. It requires getting money to people to spend it.

2. Inequality encourages financial speculation. What do the Rich do when they have so much money they cannot remember how many houses they own? They speculate with it. There is a definite correlation.. http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1661746

What does wild speculation do? See 1929 & 2008

My question is, why do 280 million Americans allow a small group of 30 million Americans have 75% of all America's wealth?

"America is good at building things. "

Not any more. It's been off-shored and outsourced. Somehow the geniuses responsible think international workers and competition won't be able to do the easier work of management. They were warned but nobody listened, nobody cared. It was all about the short-term gain for the moment.

Several years ago, Lester Thurow, then dean of MIT's Sloan School of Management, wrote about the difference in philosophy of the three major North American countries.

Mexico is a country of the past. The present is demoralizing, the future is foreboding while the past was glorious.

Canada is a country of the present. The past is subsumed by the interests of someone else (Britain/France/US) while the future viability of the country is uncertain. Today is well run, efficient and pleasant. Live for today.

The US is the country of the future. It is divorced from its past. Today is not good enough. The future holds promise.

America is good at building things. it is not good at maintaining them. A brand new bridge, a great powerful dam, a rocket to the moon, all feasible. Making the trains run on time, fixing potholes on the road, getting reliably cheap efficient environmentally conscious energy to people - all unsexy activities that are beyond American capabilities.

When we buy a car, we know that we will have to spend money to maintain it. When we buy a house, it requires constant work to make it livable. The projects spurred by the Great Society, the New Deal or during the industrial expansion of the 19th century could not propel itself. Progress requires money, manpower and collaboration between government and the private sector to continue success. It's an endless process, but it is also a most honorable and necessary one.

The unpleasant "business" of running prisons  and waging wars cannot be outsourced to private for-profit organizations. Surely there have been sufficient awful experiences in recent years for us to have learned that lesson. It seems that the profit motive brings lawlessness and greed into all of these activities. Outsourcing such profoundly important matters allows our society to avoid thinking hard and reflecting on the consequences of taking lives.

Mr. Thomason's comments, as always, are astute and on target. Nevertheless, I think there is another way to view this essay. It overlooks the alternative to the economic growth promoted by capitalism. It is globalization that has made it possible for China to feed its people and that creates the potential for Africa to escape chronic poverty. In the absence of globalization, it would not be zombies or vampires we would confront, but large numbers of people dead from starvation or epidemic disease.

And to describe consumers as mindless and soulless is simply perverse. The public does not simply buy anything dumped on to the market; if it did, there would be far fewer business failures, and the quality of products would remain dismal. (The automobile and computer industries demonstrate the positive impact of competition.) Capitalism has many faults, and those shortcomings may eventually destroy it. But this essay, with its heavy reliance on gothic metaphors, obscures more than it enlightens.

John McD:  Are you hoping for some version of Lake Wobegon, where every league in the world is a first-tier league?  The vast majority of the countries in the world have domestic leagues that are not on a par with La Liga, the Premier League. etc., and they manage somehow.

Obviously not every country has, or can support, or ever will be able to support, a league on the level of La Liga, the Bundesliga or the EPL. Look at Holland, Portugal, Denmark, Greece and most other leagues in Europe. And of course "they manage". But MLS aspires to be more, and oversells itself on a regular basis. It's great that MLS exists, and its prudent approach has no doubt helped it to survive this long. I'm just pointing out that the pay structure is a little unfair and that it's a problem for the league that the quality of the product they put on the field doesn't compare well to what people can see on TV all weekend long from other countries. At some point they need to make some bigger steps up in quality. Bringing in a few big names on the backside of their careers and overpaying(and overhyping)them is not a long-term solution.

When you watch games from Europe and then watch an MLS match-as so many did this past Saturday, watching Barcelona-Real Madrid and then Seattle-LA-the position of MLS is clear.
